JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Elisabeth Steiner;George Nicolaou;Giorgio Malinverni;Khanlar Hajiyev
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in LOC . The application is lodged on her behalf by her father , PERSON . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by PERSON PERSON , former Representative of GPE at ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant was born to PERSON and PERSON , a NORP citizen of NORP ethnic origin . The applicant ’s mother was HIV - positive ; she also suffered from tuberculosis , hepatitis and a number of other diseases .

On DATE the applicant was born in ORG no . CARDINAL . The birth was premature and the applicant suffered from serious health problems , in particular , respiratory troubles , a non - expanding lung , third - degree prenatal malnutrition , central nervous system affliction caused by oxygen deprivation in utero , foetal infection , conjugated jaundice and rickets . The mother chose not to put the father ’s name on the birth certificate because the applicant was born out of wedlock and the father was serving a prison sentence at the time .
On DATE the mother , being unable to perform parental duties , waived her parental authority in favour of ORG .
On DATE the applicant was transferred to the pathology ward for babies of ORG no . CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was diagnosed with cerebral oedema .

On DATE ORG ordered the transfer of the applicant into ORG care and her placement in ORG ( Дом ребенка ) . However , the applicant remained in ORG no . CARDINAL . On DATE she was transferred to ORG . She was kept in an isolation ward in the infectious diseases section of the hospital as a child born to an ORG mother .

According to the applicant ’s father , the ward was overcrowded , the babies were underfed , they were not taken out for walks and did not have outdoor clothing , and sanitary requirements were not respected . He also alleged that the applicant ’s health had deteriorated in the hospital and that her development was retarded . The applicant ’s father submitted no documents to corroborate his allegations and it appears that he did not visit the applicant in the hospital .

According to the Government , in ORG the applicant was placed in a ward that measured QUANTITY with CARDINAL other babies with similar diagnosis : prenatal contact with an HIV - positive mother . The ward corresponded to the requirements of ORG . It contained a bed for each baby , a cupboard , a nappy changing table , toys and baby care products . Babies were provided with both indoor and outdoor clothes . Crockery was provided individually for each baby . It was cleansed in compliance with sanitary requirements . The ward was washed CARDINAL or CARDINAL times every day with special products authorised for use in children ’s hospitals . Thorough cleansing of the wards was conducted once in DATE . During this time the babies were placed in a different ward which had already been cleansed .

Nurses washed , dressed and bathed the babies and changed their linen on a DATE basis . They took them out for walks in accordance with sanitary requirements and medical indications . Nurses also attended to the babies so they could develop various skills corresponding to their age , such as sitting up , walking or holding a spoon .

On being admitted to ORG the applicant was examined by an immunologist and a neuropathologist . She was diagnosed with prenatal damage to the nervous system of hypoxic genesis , pyramidal insufficiency , psychomotor and speech retardation , rickets and anaemia . She underwent HIV tests on DATE and DATE and DATE and DATE , all of which were negative . She underwent blood tests on DATE and DATE , DATE and DATE and a biochemical blood test on DATE . In ORG the applicant also underwent electrocardiogram and ultrasonic scanning of internal organs . She was also examined a number of times by otolaryngologists , ophthalmologists , surgeons , neuropathologists and dermatologists .

The applicant was examined DATE by a doctor and permanently cared for by the ward ’s nurse and a hospital attendant . The nurse fed the applicant CARDINAL or CARDINAL times a day and carried out medical interventions prescribed by the doctor . All parenteral interventions were carried out using disposable instruments . The babies’ temperatures were taken DATE .
The Government enclosed extracts from the applicant ’s medical file and ORG internal documents to corroborate their submissions .
On DATE the applicant was transferred from ORG to ORG .

On DATE and DATE the applicant was examined by a paediatrician who stated , in particular , that her state of health was satisfactory , she was receiving sufficient nutrition , could walk independently , spoke in syllables and played with toys .

On DATE the applicant ’s mother died of tuberculosis . Some time later the applicant ’s father was released from prison and returned to the town . He brought proceedings seeking the acknowledgement of his paternity vis - à - vis the applicant .

On DATE the ORG established paternity on the part of the applicant ’s father . On DATE ORG ordered the applicant ’s transfer to her father ’s custody and DATE he took the applicant from the orphanage .

On DATE the father brought proceedings before ORG on the applicant ’s behalf against the social security office and the finance office of ORG , claiming non - pecuniary damages for the applicant ’s allegedly unlawful placement in LOC . He maintained that , instead of having been transferred to a specialised institution , ORG , his daughter had been kept for DATE in the isolation ward of the hospital , as a result of which she had allegedly contracted conjugated jaundice , damage to the central nervous system , dystrophy , chicken pox and anaemia and her development was retarded . He claimed , on behalf of the applicant , MONEY ( RUB ) in respect of non - pecuniary damage .

On an unspecified date ORG granted the applicant ’s father ’s request to order a medical expert examination of the applicant with the purpose of establishing a cause and effect relationship between the applicant ’s placement in the hospital and her state of health . It was ordered at the father ’s expense . However , he refused to pay for it , and the court proceeded with the case without conducting the examination .

On DATE ORG dismissed the claim in full as unsubstantiated . The court established that the placement of the applicant in the hospital was lawful and served the interests of the child . The father appealed .
On DATE ORG upheld the decision of CARDINAL DATE .

The courts at both instances examined the applicant ’s father ’s allegations that her placement at ORG was unlawful . They did not examine the allegations of inadequate conditions and treatment in the hospital since those had not been properly raised . ORG specifically noted in its decision of DATE that the applicant ’s father did not make a claim for damages against ORG , which remained open to him .

On an unspecified date in DATE the father wrote a letter to the regional office of ORG seeking institution of criminal proceedings against various officials of ORG alleging that , while the applicant ’s mother was pregnant with her , certain doctors or social workers had tried to persuade her to have an abortion .
On DATE the Deputy ORG decided not to open a criminal investigation in that respect . The applicant complained to a higher prosecutor about the refusal .
On DATE ORG of LOC informed the applicant ’s father that his complaint was dismissed and the refusal to open criminal investigation was upheld . The applicant ’s father did not appeal to a court .

The applicant ’s father maintained that their family was constantly discriminated against on the ground of their NORP origin . In particular , the applicant had allegedly been denied free hospitalisation in the town hospital when she had bronchitis . Furthermore , a municipal official had allegedly shouted at them , suggesting that they should “ pack themselves off to GPE ” .

On DATE the father applied to ORG seeking institution of a criminal investigation . He alleged that on DATE a group of people , according to him , social security workers accompanied by a policeman , had come to his flat , had tried to abduct the applicant and had stolen MONEY .
On DATE the complaint was transferred to the Biysk town police department .
On DATE the police opened a criminal investigation into the alleged theft .
On DATE the investigation was suspended for failure to identify the culprits .
The applicant ’s father then complained to ORG that ORG had taken no action in connection with his allegations of trespassing and “ attempted hostage taking ” .
On DATE ORG allowed the complaint . The decision was upheld by ORG on DATE .
On DATE ORG refused to institute criminal proceedings into the allegation of trespassing and “ attempted hostage taking ” . The applicant ’s father complained about the refusal to ORG .
On DATE ORG dismissed the complaint and found the refusal to be lawful . ORG upheld the decision on DATE .

The decision to suspend the investigation into the alleged theft of DATE was quashed on an unspecified date . However , the investigation was again suspended on DATE . The applicant ’s father also tried unsuccessfully to institute several sets of criminal proceedings against police and prosecution officials involved in the investigation .

LAW provides that a court or a justice of peace may exempt a party to the proceedings from payment of , inter alia , costs related to expert fees or reduce such costs , taking into account the party ’s financial state .
